channel.title: NYT > Books
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: How a Group of Heretical Thinkers Chipped Away at the Idea of ‘Us’ and ‘Them’
item.description: “Gods of the Upper Air,” by Charles King, tells the story of the anthropologist Franz Boas and those he influenced, including Margaret Mead and Zora Neale Hurston.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Szalai
item.category: Gods of the Upper Air: How a Circle of Renegade Anthropologists Reinvented Race, Sex, and Gender in the Twentieth Century (Book)

item.title: Jia Tolentino Wants You to Read Children’s Books
item.description: “A really good middle-grade novel,” says the New Yorker essayist, whose debut collection is “Trick Mirror,” “will supersede a lot of contemporary fiction in terms of economy, lucidity and grace.”

item.title: ‘Abnormal, as Most Geniuses Are’: Celebrating 200 Years of Herman Melville
item.description: The Times has not always given the writer his due. Here’s a look at how we covered him and his most famous novel, ‘Moby-Dick,’ over the past century or two.
item.dc:creator: Tina Jordan
item.media:description: When Herman Melville died in 1891, The New York Times barely noted it, listing his obituary after a civil engineer, “the best known criminal lawyer in Connecticut” and “the oldest resident of the Oranges.”

item.title: 11 New Books to Watch For in August
item.description: Jia Tolentino’s essay collection, a highly anticipated new novel from Téa Obreht, a Japanese thriller and more.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib
item.category: Drive Your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead (Book)
Inconspicuous Consumption: An Obsessive Look at the Stuff We Take for Granted, from the Everyday to the Obscure (Book)
A Particular Kind of Black Man (Book)
White Flights: Race, Fiction, and the American Imagination (Book)

item.title: What Moves Nina Stibbe Most in a Book? ‘Dogs’
item.description: The British author, whose latest novel is “Reasons to Be Cheerful,” says that “fictional animals were fundamental to my early reading and continue to score high, emotionally.”

item.title: Fiction About Unprecedented Situations
item.description: Ted Chiang talks about “Exhalation,” and Helen Phillips discusses “The Need.”

item.title: Picture Books to Perk Up Any Kid’s Summer
item.description: The story behind sea glass, a walrus who helps you learn to swim, a cat and a dog on the run, and more in books from Cori Doerrfeld, Calef Brown and others.
item.category: Grandpa Cacao: A Tale of Chocolate, from Farm to Family (Book)
Up Verses Down: Poems, Paintings, and Serious Nonsense (Book)

item.title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
item.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.

item.title: The Man Who Tried to Catch the 100-Pound Salmon
item.description: In “Stronghold,” Tucker Malarkey profiles her cousin, Guido Rahr, who has made it his life mission to conserve the salmon of Russia’s Far East.
item.dc:creator: Nate Blakeslee

item.title: Edward Snowden’s Memoir Is Coming in September
item.description: The National Security Agency whistle-blower has written a book exploring his role in mass surveillance and the “crisis of conscience” that led to his actions.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León

item.title: Spain’s Most Celebrated Writer Believes the Fascist Past Is Still Present
item.description: Javier Marías has spent his career chronicling his country’s moral trade-off with its violent history.
item.dc:creator: Giles Harvey
item.media:credit: Gianfranco Tripodo for The New York Times

item.title: Irish Band Channels the Spirit of Punk, and James Joyce
item.description: Fontaines D.C. is a breakout Irish rock act. The emphasis is on the Irish.
item.dc:creator: Amos Barshad
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Carlos O’Connell, Conor Curley, Conor Deegan, Grian Chatten and Tom Coll make up the Irish rock band Fontaines D.C.

item.title: The Ideas Flow in Hervé Tullet’s Studio
item.description: The French-born illustrator behind “Press Here” and other children’s books strives for “no barrier” between inspiration and the finished product.
item.dc:creator: Maria Russo
item.media:credit: Caroline Tompkins for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Sometimes I feel the space here is too small,” Tullet said. “But then that also makes me feel more free. Because this isn’t really my studio — my studio is in my brain.”

item.title: Unearthed Steinbeck Short Story Isn’t at All Like ‘Grapes of Wrath’
item.description: The quintessentially American author wrote pieces for a Paris newspaper in the 1950s. Now, one of those — about a nervous chef and a magnificent cat — is being published in English for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.category: Ransom, Harry, Center, The University of Texas at Austin
item.media:description: John Steinbeck and his wife, Elaine, in 1954, the year he wrote a series of pieces that ran in Le Figaro, a French newspaper.

item.title: Agnes Heller, 90, Hungarian Philosopher and Outspoken Dissident, Is Dead
item.description: Since the 1950s, she had been a thorn in the side of authoritarian governments on the left and the right, including Viktor Orban’s today.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Old Men and the Sea (or, Richard Russo’s New Novel)
item.description: “Chances Are...,” about college friends who reunite one weekend on Martha’s Vineyard, is tinged with regret and melancholy.
item.dc:creator: Alida Becker

item.title: She Was Filipino Food’s Greatest Champion. Now Her Work Is Finding New Fans.
item.description: Years after her death, the writer Doreen Gamboa Fernandez is gaining a following among Filipino-American chefs for the way she explored the cuisine from the bottom up.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan

item.title: You Can Read Yuval Noah Harari’s Book in Russian, Except for the Parts About Russia
item.description: The translation of “21 Lessons for the 21st Century” removed or altered passages critical of Putin’s administration, as well as references to the author’s sexuality.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuval Noah Harari agreed to some changes to his book “21 Lessons for the 21st Century” when it was translated into Russian. “It’s important to reach people in nondemocratic societies,” he said, “and for that you have to make compromises.”

item.title: A Defense of the Semicolon and Other Adventures in the English Language
item.description: Four new books examine our language from various angles — historical, political and grammatical.
item.dc:creator: Patricia T. O’Conner
item.category: Wordslut: A Feminist Guide to Taking Back the English Language (Book)
The Dictionary Wars: The American Fight Over the English Language (Book)
Semicolon: The Past, Present, and Future of a Misunderstood Mark (Book)

item.title: The Bohemian Life of the French Composer Erik Satie Imagined as a Novel
item.description: “The Vexations,” a debut by Caitlin Horrocks, places the avant-garde composer within the colorful world of fin-de-siècle Paris and at the center of a family drama.
item.dc:creator: Seth Colter Walls

item.title: A Girl Goes Missing. A Loner Takes Her Place.
item.description: Sarah Elaine Smith’s debut novel, “Marilou Is Everywhere,” is a coming-of-age mystery that’s also about what it’s like to be an outsider.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Khong

item.title: New & Noteworthy Books, From Italian History to Asian Politics
item.description: A selection of recent books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.

item.title: Natural Wines, Explained
item.description: Alice Feiring’s new book takes a deep dive into the additive-free world of winemaking.
item.dc:creator: Florence Fabricant
item.category: Natural Wine for the People: What It Is, Where to Find It, How to Love It (Book)

item.title: Have You Seen ‘Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood’? Here’s What to Read
item.description: Five books about or inspired by Charles Manson give insight into one of the 20th century’s most notorious crime sprees.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León
item.category: The Family: The Story of Charles Manson's Dune Buggy Attack Battalion (Book)
Manson: The Life and Times of Charles Manson (Book)
Chaos: Charles Manson, the C.I.A. and the Secret History of the Sixties (Book)

item.title: The Lives of Four Andover Grads Cut Short
item.description: In “Four Friends,” William D. Cohan examines what happened to four alumni of the famous prep school, including John F. Kennedy Jr.
item.dc:creator: Janny Scott

item.title: What Do Kurt Vonnegut, Vladimir Nabokov and Nora Ephron Have in Common?
item.description: They all wrote for The New York Times Book Review.
item.dc:creator: Tina Jordan
item.category: Love in the Time of Cholera (Book)
item.media:credit: Photo credits, from left: Oliver Morris/Getty Images, Hulton-Deutsch/Getty Images, Ray Howard/Associated Press
item.media:description: From left: Kurt Vonnegut Jr., Vladimir Nabokov and Nora Ephron, all former New York Times book reviewers.

item.title: Bryan Magee, Who Brought Philosophy to British TV, Dies at 89
item.description: Mr. Magee was a philosopher, writer and politician who challenged the idea that television could not “make serious demands on viewers.”
item.dc:creator: Palko Karasz
item.media:credit: Chris Ridley/Radio Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The British philosopher and TV personality Bryan Magee in 1976. He believed that on television, ideas could be as entertaining as images.

item.title: Journalist Misses His Deadline on Manson Article. By 20 Years.
item.description: Tom O’Neill, the author of a new book about the Manson murders, finds that the accepted narrative of the crimes doesn’t quite add up.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: Charles Manson entering the Los Angeles city jail in December 1969.

item.title: In ‘Idiot Wind,’ a Lost Soul Finds His Way Home
item.description: Peter Kaldheim talks about leaving his life behind, his book’s 30-year gestation and the kindred spirit he sees in Tom Waits.
item.dc:creator: John Williams

item.title: A da Vinci for Any Budget
item.description: On the 500th anniversary of Leonardo’s death, three new coffee-table books revisit the life and legacy of the original Renaissance man.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Christensen

item.title: Four Wall Street Bankers Are Stuck in an Elevator — and It’s No Joke
item.description: In Megan Goldin’s debut thriller, “The Escape Room,” cutthroat colleagues must figure out how to get out of an escape room and save their lives.
item.dc:creator: Rene Denfeld

item.title: 50 States of True Crime
item.description: Every state has an infamous crime — and a book about it.
item.dc:creator: Tina Jordan and Ross MacDonald

item.title: Down but Not Out: Fiction Filled With Second Chances
item.description: Three new novels trace the experiences of a sad sack bachelor, a lonely gardener and three women with ties to a home for “fallen” young ladies.
item.dc:creator: Michael Callahan
item.category: Home for Erring and Outcast Girls (Book)

item.title: Solace and Salvation in the Marvel Universe, at 12 Cents a Comic Book
item.description: How Jack Kirby, Steve Ditko and Stan Lee shaped one boy’s life at a time when his family was in deep distress.
item.dc:creator: Dana Jennings

item.title: Why the ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Author Returned to Prison
item.description: Piper Kerman, whose experiences and memoir inspired the Netflix prison dramedy, now works with inmates in correctional facilities.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.category: Orange Is the New Black (TV Program)

item.title: We Asked 13 Novelists, From Lee Child to Ruth Ware, ‘What’s the Best Murder You Ever Wrote?’
item.description: Karin Slaughter killed a character with antifreeze; Peter Swanson used cashews and a missing EpiPen. Welcome to the devious minds of thriller writers.
item.dc:creator: Tammy Tarng

item.title: What if Hercule Poirot Went Sleuthing on the L Train?
item.description: Ali Fitzgerald imagines Agatha Christie’s famous detective on a hunt for clues through the New York City subways.
item.dc:creator: Ali Fitzgerald

item.title: Taxidermy, Velvet and Candlelight: A Lush Victorian Horror Story
item.description: In Elizabeth Macneal’s debut novel, “The Doll Factory,” a taxidermist becomes obsessed with a young painter.
item.dc:creator: Lyndsay Faye

item.title: Can Communists Be Good Americans?
item.description: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.

item.title: A Dystopian Cocktail, Served Chilled With a Twist
item.description: In Juli Zeh’s “Empty Hearts,” a German businesswoman runs a start-up that matches despondent people with terrorist organizations in need of suicide bombers.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sternbergh

item.title: New in Paperback: ‘The Family Tabor,’ ‘Into the Hands of the Soldiers’
item.description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib

item.title: How Did We Get From Compassionate Conservatism to the Party of Trump?
item.description: Tim Alberta speaks to us about “American Carnage,” his gripping new account of the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: Emily Eakin
item.category: American Carnage: On the Front Lines of the Republican Civil War and the Rise of President Trump (Book)
item.media:description: President Trump delivers his State of the Union Address in February, as Vice President Mike Pence, left, applauds.

item.title: Your Therapist’s Prescription? The Right Book.
item.description: Lori Gottlieb analyzes the benefits — and side effects — of bibliotherapy.
item.dc:creator: Lori Gottlieb

item.title: She Grew Up in a House Without Books. A Teacher Helped Her Realize She Could Write One Herself.
item.description: At the end of her sophomore year in college, Mary Beth Keane’s writing teacher gave her a summer reading list that changed her life.
item.dc:creator: Mary Beth Keane

item.title: Margaret Fulton Brought the World to the Australian Table
item.description: It’s hard to overstate the cultural impact of the prolific Australian author, who propelled nearly an entire generation toward more open-minded cooking.
item.dc:creator: Tacey Rychter
